definition:
A *right trapezoid* is a trapezoid that has at least two right angles.
Below is a picture of a right trapezoid.

(0,0)(4,2) (0,0)(1,2)(4,2)(4,0)

In some dialects of English ( British English), this figure is referred
to as a *right trapezium*. Because of the modifier “right”, no confusion
should arise with this usage.

All rectangles are right trapezoids (unless the definition of trapezoid
is used, see the entry on for more details). Note also that, in
Euclidean geometry, a trapezoid cannot have an odd number of right
angles.

A is a trapezoid that is simultaneously a right trapezoid and an
isosceles trapezoid. In Euclidean geometry, such trapezoids are
automatically rectangles. In hyperbolic geometry, such trapezoids are
automatically Saccheri quadrilaterals. Thus, the phrase “right isosceles
trapezoid” occurs rarely.

Right trapezoids are used in the trapezoidal rule and composite
trapezoidal rule for estimating Riemann integrals.
